sequence.notes: Dichlorination of an alkene to form a vicinal dichloride with defined relative stereochemistry.
Oxidation of a primary alcohol to an aldehyde, preserving the stereochemistry of the adjacent chiral centers.
Aldehyde undergoes chain extension with a vinyl aluminum reagent, followed by epoxidation.

Alkene cross-metathesis between the terminal vinyl group of the reactant and the 1-chloro-1,9-decadiene reagent. The catalyst is a Hoveyda-Grubbs type ruthenium carbene complex. The stereochemistry of the epoxide and dichloro-methyl groups in the reactant is preserved in the product. The newly formed double bond at the epoxide is Z-configured, and the terminal double bond in the product is E-configured. Significant discrepancies were noted between the provided catalyst SMILES and the drawn structure regarding the N-heterocyclic carbene (NHC) ligand and the 'O3N' ligand. The provided SMILES for the NHC ligand does not match the 'NMes' and adamantyl-like structure shown in the image. The 'O3N' label might refer to nitrate (NO3-), but the provided SMILES represents a nitro group (NO2).
Epoxide ring opening with chloride nucleophile, activated by boron trifluoride etherate.
Stereoselective anti-dichlorination of an E-alkene. The alcohol and other stereocenters, as well as the terminal E-alkene, are retained.
